Description: THE TASKS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS PROJECT WILL HELP IMPROVE THE UNDERSTANDING OF THE RED SNAPPER FISHERY AND OTHER REEF-ASSOCIATED SPECIES IN THE SOUTH ATLANTIC REGION. THIS MULTIFACETED APPROACH IS NEEDED TO:   ADDRESS DISCARD MORTALITY OF RED SNAPPER,   UNDERSTAND HOW STAKEHOLDERS ARE ADOPTING BEST FISHING PRACTICES (BFPS),   FURTHER ENGAGE STAKEHOLDERS IN THE MANAGEMENT PROCESS,   ADDRESS STAKEHOLDERS' CONCERNS, AND   IMPROVE THE TRANSITION FROM REVIEW OF THE SOUTH ATLANTIC RED SNAPPER RESEARCH PROJECT (SARSRP) TO USE OF THE INFORMATION IN THE SOUTH ATLANTIC RED SNAPPER RESEARCH TRACK STOCK ASSESSMENT.

FUNDS WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT THE FOLLOWING PROJECTS: AMERICAN SAMOA: 1. U.S. PACIFIC TERRITORIES FISHERY CAPACITY-BUILDING SCHOLARSHIP PROGRAM  2. MARINE CONSERVATION PLAN PROJECT COORDINATOR  3. FEASIBILITY STUDY FOR WEST TUTUILA BOAT RAMP  4. FAGASA BOAT RAMP REPAIR  5. PAGO BOAT RAMP REPAIR

FUNDS WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT THE FOLLOWING PROJECTS: COMMONWEALTH OF THE NORTHERN MARIANAS ISLANDS 1. U.S. PACIFIC TERRITORIES FISHERY CAPACITY-BUILDING SCHOLARSHIP PROGRAM ($50,000) - THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT ONE STUDENT ORIGINATING FROM CNMI FOR TWO SEMESTERS AND ONE SUMMER INTERNSHIP. THE STUDENT WILL BE TRANSITIONING FROM A COMMUNITY COLLEGE TO A FOUR YEAR COLLEGE/UNIVERSITY IN HAWAII OR GUAM TO COMPLETE THEIR JUNIOR OR SENIOR YEAR TOWARD EARNING A FISHERY-RELATED BACHELOR'S OR A STUDENT WITH A BACHELOR OF SCIENCE DEGREE WORKING TO COMPLETE A GRADUATE LEVEL DEGREE. THE PARTICIPATING STUDENT, UPON GRADUATION, WILL BE REQUIRED TO WORK FOR THEIR LOCAL FISHERY-RELATED AGENCY FOR ONE YEAR FOR EACH YEAR THE SCHOLARSHIP WAS RECEIVED. THE SCHOLARSHIP PROGRAM PROVIDES SUPPORT FOR RECIPIENT TRAVEL-RELATED EXPENSES TO ATTEND THE UNIVERSITY AND PARTICIPATE IN THE INTERNSHIP AND SUBSEQUENT EMPLOYMENT WITH A FISHERY-MANAGEMENT AGENCY, TUITION, BOOKS AND FEES, INTERNSHIP COMPENSATION, HOUSING

THIS PROPOSAL WILL PROVIDE FINANCIAL SUPPORT ONE STUDENT TO PARTICIPATE IN THE CAPACITY BUILDING SCHOLARSHIP PROGRAM FOR ONE YEAR. THE SCHOLARSHIP PROGRAM PROVIDES SUPPORT FOR RECIPIENT TRAVEL-RELATED EXPENSES TO ATTEND THE UNIVERSITY AND PARTICIPATE IN THE INTERNSHIP AND SUBSEQUENT EMPLOYMENT WITH A FISHERY-MANAGEMENT AGENCY, TUITION, BOOKS AND FEES, INTERNSHIP COMPENSATION, HOUSING/DORMITORY ACCOMMODATIONS, BOARD AND OTHER RELATED EXPENSES.  THIS PROPOSAL WILL ALSO SUPPORT COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND DIALOGUE AROUND THE FISHERIES MANAGEMENT ISSUES AND THE IMPLEMENTATION OF ACTIVITIES LISTED IN THE PRIA MCP. A SERIES OF COMMUNITY MEETINGS WILL BE HELD TO CONVENE THE COMMUNITY AND GAIN THEIR PERSPECTIVES AROUND HOW TO BEST UTILIZE OR MODIFY FISHERY MANAGEMENT PROCESS AND/OR REGULATIONS TO ADVANCE EQUITY. FOR EXAMPLE, AS PART OF THE WP COUNCIL'S EQUITY AND ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE ASSESSMENT HELD IN 2021 AND 2022, FISHING COMMUNITIES HAVE IDENTIFIED SEVERAL MECHANISMS IN MSA AND REGULATIONS

THROUGH THIS AWARD THE WESTERN PACIFIC REGIONAL FISHERY MANAGEMENT COUNCIL WILL FILL-IN GAPS AND FURTHER THE KNOWLEDGE ON CORAL REEF FISH SPECIES IN ORDER TO MORE ACCURATELY ASSESS AND MONITOR THE STOCKS AND SUPPORT ECOSYSTEM FISHERY MANAGEMENT IN THE U.S. TERRITORIES. THE COUNCIL WILL 1) SUPPORT STAFF WORKING ON CORAL REEF ECOSYSTEM ASSESSMENT, CONSERVATION, AND MANAGEMENT WITHIN THE WESTERN PACIFIC; 2) CONTINUE TO SUPPORT A SHALLOW CORAL REEF FISHERY BIOSAMPLING PROGRAM FOR AMERICAN SAMOA, GUAM, AND THE COMMONWEALTH OF THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS TO ADDRESS LIFE HISTORY DATA GAPS FOR KEY SPECIES; AND 3) DEVELOP ECOSYSTEM-BASED FISHERIES MANAGEMENT INDICATORS FOR THE CORAL REEF FISHERIES OF THE MARIANA ARCHIPELAGO BY ASSESSING THE ASSOCIATIONS BETWEEN LEVELS OF TARGET FISH BIOMASS (AS AN INDICATOR OF FISHING INTENSITY) AND A SUITE OF METRICS REFLECTING THE STATE OF THE CORAL REEF ECOSYSTEM AT ISLAND SCALE.

THROUGH THIS AWARD, THE SOUTH ATLANTIC FISHERY MANAGEMENT COUNCIL WILL 1) SUPPORT A BIOLOGIST TO ASSIST IN THE MANAGEMENT OF THE SOUTH ATLANTIC CORAL RESOURCES UNDER THE COUNCIL'S CORAL, CORAL REEF AND LIVE/HARD BOTTOM HABITAT FISHERY MANAGEMENT PLAN, REVIEW OTHER FISHERY MANAGEMENT PLANS TO ENSURE PROTECTION OF CORALS AND CORAL REEFS, INTEGRATE NEW CORAL HABITAT SUITABILITY MAPS INTO MANAGEMENT, AND COMMENT ON DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS THROUGH ESSENTIAL FISH HABITAT CONSULTATIONS AS NEEDED; 2) CONTINUE TO SUPPORT MESOPHOTIC CORAL REEF ASSESSMENT OFF THE FLORIDA KEYS THROUGH HABITAT MAPPING AND DIVER SURVEYS IN ORDER TO BETTER TRACK CHANGES IN FISH ABUNDANCE; AND 3) DEVELOP A CITIZEN SCIENCE PROJECT IN CONJUNCTION WITH REEF ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION FOUNDATION AND  SOUTHEAST COASTAL OCEAN OBSERVING REGIONAL ASSOCIATION IN WHICH RECREATIONAL DIVERS WILL GATHER FISH LENGTH DATA FOR POTENTIAL USE IN STOCK ASSESSMENTS AND INTEGRATED ECOSYSTEM APPROACHES.

THE GULF OF MEXICO FISHERY MANAGEMENT COUNCIL WILL CONDUCT A SERIES OF DESKTOP ANALYSES USING PREVIOUSLY COLLECTED DATA TO AID IN THE MANAGEMENT OF FEDERAL FISHERIES RESOURCES AND SUPPORT COUNCIL ACTIVITIES. THE COUNCIL WILL CONDUCT A SERIES OF ANALYSIS RELATED TO THREE TASKS. FOR TASK 1, THE COUNCIL WILL IDENTIFY CORAL REEF AREAS THAT MAY BENEFIT FROM ADDITIONAL CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS, INCLUDING RE-EVALUATING AREAS THAT WERE UNDER CONSIDERATION AS HABITAT AREAS OF PARTICULAR CONCERN BUT NOT INCLUDED IN PREVIOUS COUNCIL ACTIONS OR MARINE SANCTUARY DESIGNATIONS. FOR TASK 2, THE COUNCIL WILL INCORPORATE ESSENTIAL FISH HABITAT DATA TO IMPROVE DELINEATION AND MANAGEMENT OF CORAL-RELATED ESSENTIAL FISH HABITAT IN THE GULF. FOR TASK 3, THE COUNCIL WILL DEVELOP INDICATORS FOR MONITORING CORAL REEF CONDITIONS IN THE GULF THROUGH CITIZEN SCIENCE AND DATA COLLABORATION WITH PARTNERS.  THE COUNCIL WILL PRODUCE WHITE PAPERS FOR USE BY THE COUNCIL'S COMMITTEES AND WEB STORIES TO PROVID

HE CARIBBEAN FISHERY MANAGEMENT COUNCIL WILL PROVIDE FUNDING TO THREE CONTRACTORS TO DO A COORDINATED VISUAL, ACOUSTIC, AND OCEANOGRAPHIC ASSESSMENT OF KEY GROUPER SPAWNING AGGREGATIONS SITES OFF THE SOUTHWEST OF PUERTO RICO AND EAST COAST OF ST. CROIX, U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS, WHICH ARE KNOWN SPAWNING AGGREGATION SITES FOR RED HIND (EPINEPHELUS GUTTATUS). THE COUNCIL WILL QUANTIFY RED HIND REPRODUCTIVE ACTIVITY AND RELATIVE ABUNDANCES AT KNOWN SPAWNING AGGREGATION SITES TO 1) MEASURE ABUNDANCE OF GROUPERS IN-SITU WITH MULTIPLE TECHNOLOGIES (I.E., DIVER UNDERWATER VISUAL CENSUS, STEREO DIVER OPERATED VIDEO, REMOTELY OPERATED VEHICLE VIDEO, AND PASSIVE ACOUSTIC MONITORING); 2) DETERMINE THE TEMPORAL VARIABILITY IN SOUND PRODUCTION AND ABUNDANCE OF GROUPERS; AND 3) DEVELOP A MONITORING SURVEY DESIGN FOR GROUPER SPAWNING AGGREGATION SITES THAT CAN BE DEPLOYED REMOTELY AND REPLICATED IN DIFFERENT DEPTHS, HABITATS AND LOCATIONS. THIS PROPOSAL WILL FUND 2 PROJECTS:  THE FIRST PROJECT WILL SUPPORT ONE STUDENT ORIGINATING FROM AMERICAN SAMOA FOR TWO SEMESTERS AND ONE SUMMER INTERNSHIP. THE STUDENT WILL BE TRANSITIONING FROM A COMMUNITY COLLEGE TO A FOUR YEAR COLLEGE/UNIVERSITY IN HAWAII OR GUAM TO COMPLETE THEIR JUNIOR OR SENIOR YEAR TOWARD EARNING A FISHERY-RELATED BACHELOR'S OR A STUDENT WITH A BACHELOR OF SCIENCE DEGREE WORKING TO COMPLETE A GRADUATE LEVEL DEGREE. THE PARTICIPATING STUDENT, UPON GRADUATION, WILL BE REQUIRED TO WORK FOR THEIR LOCAL FISHERY-RELATED AGENCY FOR ONE YEAR FOR EACH YEAR THE SCHOLARSHIP WAS RECEIVED. THE SCHOLARSHIP PROGRAM PROVIDES SUPPORT FOR RECIPIENT TRAVEL-RELATED EXPENSES TO ATTEND THE UNIVERSITY AND PARTICIPATE IN THE INTERNSHIP AND SUBSEQUENT EMPLOYMENT WITH A FISHERY-MANAGEMENT AGENCY, TUITION, BOOKS AND FEES, INTERNSHIP COMPENSATION, HOUSING/DORMITORY ACCOMMODATIONS, BOARD AND OTHER RELATED EXPENSES.
